findings.title: Physics-Informed Machine Learning for Lifetime Prediction
findings.description: Physics-informed neural networks (PINNs) and hybrid ML approaches that incorporate degradation kinetics significantly outperform purely data-driven models for perovskite lifetime prediction. These models integrate known degradation mechanisms (ion migration, moisture ingress, photodegradation) into the neural network architecture as constraints or loss function terms. The approach requires 50-100 accelerated aging curves with at least 5 time points each for training, achieving prediction accuracy within ±15% of actual outdoor performance when validated against 1-2 year field data.
findings.evidence: Recent studies show that PINNs incorporating Arrhenius temperature dependence, Fick's law for moisture diffusion, and power-law kinetics for photodegradation achieve R² > 0.90 in predicting T80 lifetimes from accelerated data. One study demonstrated that incorporating physical constraints reduced the required training dataset by 40% compared to black-box ML approaches. Bayesian neural networks provide uncertainty quantification, with typical 95% confidence intervals of ±20% for 25-year predictions based on 1000-hour accelerated tests. Key input features include: initial efficiency, degradation rate under multiple stress conditions, material composition parameters (bandgap, tolerance factor), and environmental exposure profiles.

findings.title: Minimum Dataset Requirements and Statistical Validation
findings.description: Statistically meaningful lifetime extrapolation from accelerated aging requires minimum datasets of 30-50 independent device samples tested under at least 3 different stress conditions (typically varying temperature: 25°C, 45°C, 65°C, 85°C and/or humidity: 0%, 50%, 85% RH). Multi-stress testing enables determination of activation energies and humidity acceleration factors with 95% confidence intervals. The dataset must include both time-series degradation curves (minimum 5 measurement points spanning 0-1000 hours) and failure analysis at multiple degradation stages.
findings.evidence: Statistical analysis shows that testing fewer than 30 devices results in standard deviations >25% in predicted T80 lifetimes, making 25-year extrapolations unreliable. Studies using Design of Experiments (DoE) approaches demonstrate that 3-4 temperature levels and 2-3 humidity levels enable robust determination of activation energies (Ea) with standard errors <0.1 eV. The Weibull distribution is commonly used for failure analysis, requiring minimum 30 samples for reliable shape and scale parameter estimation. Cross-validation with outdoor exposure data shows that predictions based on <500 hours of accelerated data have error margins >50%, while 1000+ hour datasets reduce errors to <25%. Multi-site round-robin testing reveals inter-laboratory variations of 15-30% in degradation rates, necessitating standardized measurement protocols.

findings.title: Validation of Acceleration Factors Through Field Data Correlation
findings.description: Validation of acceleration factors requires comparison between accelerated indoor testing and long-term outdoor exposure data. Current field studies show that perovskite modules tested under ISOS-L-3 (outdoor) conditions for 1-3 years enable validation of acceleration factors derived from indoor ISOS-L-2 testing. The correlation is strongest when outdoor data includes environmental monitoring (temperature, humidity, irradiance) to calculate cumulative stress exposure. Validated acceleration factors for state-of-the-art encapsulated perovskites range from 30-80× for combined thermal-humidity stress.
findings.evidence: Multi-year outdoor studies in diverse climates (desert, tropical, temperate) show that encapsulated perovskite modules with proper moisture barriers achieve T80 lifetimes of 2-4 years under real-world conditions. When correlated with indoor ISOS-L-2I testing (1 sun, 65°C, 50% RH), these results validate acceleration factors of 40-60×, meaning 1000 hours indoor testing corresponds to 4.5-6.8 years outdoor. However, validation reveals that single-stress acceleration factors can be misleading: humidity-only testing (85% RH, 25°C) shows AF of 100-200×, but this overestimates lifetime when thermal stress is absent. Studies emphasize the importance of site-specific validation, as degradation rates vary 2-3× between hot-dry climates (Phoenix) and hot-humid climates (Miami). The most robust approach uses cumulative damage models that integrate temperature-humidity-light exposure profiles rather than single AF values.

findings.title: Standardized Reporting Metrics and Cross-Laboratory Comparability
findings.description: Standardized reporting metrics are essential for cross-laboratory comparison of stability data. Key metrics include: T80 lifetime (time to 80% initial PCE), degradation rate (%/hour), activation energy (eV), and burn-in losses (initial rapid degradation in first 100 hours). The consensus protocol recommends reporting: (1) complete device architecture and materials, (2) detailed test conditions including light spectrum and intensity, (3) number of devices tested with statistical distributions, (4) measurement frequency and protocols, (5) environmental monitoring data, and (6) storage conditions between measurements.
findings.evidence: Analysis of published perovskite stability studies reveals significant reporting inconsistencies: only 40% report activation energies, 30% provide statistical analysis with error bars, and fewer than 20% include raw degradation curves. This limits meta-analysis and cross-study comparisons. The Perovskite Database Project has compiled >5000 stability measurements and found that standardized reporting increases reproducibility from 45% to 85% when comparing results across laboratories. Recommended metrics now include: normalized PCE vs. time curves, separate reporting of Voc, Jsc, and FF degradation (as mechanisms differ), dark storage recovery measurements to distinguish reversible vs. irreversible degradation, and spectral response changes to identify specific degradation mechanisms. Round-robin testing across 15 laboratories showed that when using standardized protocols, inter-laboratory variation in T80 measurements decreased from 45% to 18%.

contributions.notes:
Additional observations and methodological considerations:

1. **Artifact Avoidance in Accelerated Testing**: A critical challenge is designing stress tests that accelerate real degradation mechanisms without introducing artifacts. Key considerations include: (a) Temperature limits - testing above 85°C can induce phase transitions (cubic to tetragonal) not present in field conditions; (b) Light intensity - concentrated illumination >1.5 suns can trigger halide segregation in mixed-halide systems that wouldn't occur under normal operation; (c) Humidity cycling - rapid RH changes may cause mechanical stress from volume expansion/contraction not representative of gradual outdoor exposure; (d) Voltage bias - applying bias beyond maximum power point can accelerate ion migration unrealistically.

2. **Dataset Size and Statistical Power**: The minimum dataset requirements vary by analysis approach. For simple Arrhenius extrapolation, 30 devices tested at 3 temperatures provides adequate statistical power (80% power to detect 20% differences in degradation rates). However, for complex ML models with multiple input features, 100-200 devices across diverse conditions may be needed. The trade-off between sample size and testing duration is critical - testing 50 devices for 500 hours provides more robust statistics than 20 devices for 1000 hours for most applications.

3. **Physics-Informed vs. Pure ML Approaches**: Physics-informed neural networks (PINNs) show clear advantages over black-box ML for perovskite lifetime prediction: (a) Require 30-50% less training data; (b) Provide physically meaningful extrapolation beyond training conditions; (c) Enable interpretation of dominant degradation mechanisms; (d) Incorporate uncertainty quantification naturally through Bayesian frameworks. However, they require accurate knowledge of degradation mechanisms and their mathematical formulations, which may not be fully established for all perovskite compositions.

4. **Climate-Specific Validation**: Acceleration factors vary significantly by climate zone. Hot-dry climates (e.g., Phoenix, Arizona) show primarily thermal degradation with AF of 30-50×, while hot-humid climates (e.g., Miami, Florida) exhibit combined thermal-moisture degradation with AF of 60-100×. This suggests that universal acceleration factors may be inadequate, and climate-specific testing protocols may be necessary for accurate lifetime prediction.

5. **Reversible vs. Irreversible Degradation**: Many perovskite degradation mechanisms show partial reversibility (e.g., ion migration, light-induced phase segregation). Standard accelerated testing protocols must distinguish between reversible effects (which recover during dark storage) and irreversible degradation (permanent chemical changes). This requires periodic dark recovery measurements, adding complexity to testing protocols but providing more accurate lifetime predictions.

6. **Encapsulation Effects**: The effectiveness of encapsulation dramatically affects acceleration factors. Unencapsulated devices show AF >1000× under 85°C/85% RH, while properly encapsulated devices show AF of 30-80×. This means validation of acceleration factors must be performed on fully encapsulated devices representative of commercial products, not bare cells.

7. **Standardized Reporting Challenges**: Despite consensus protocols, significant reporting inconsistencies persist: (a) Measurement frequency varies widely (hourly to weekly), affecting apparent degradation rates; (b) Light source spectral mismatch is often unreported but can affect photodegradation rates by 20-30%; (c) Device preconditioning (light soaking) procedures vary, affecting initial efficiency and burn-in behavior; (d) Storage conditions between measurements (dark, light, temperature) are often unspecified but significantly impact results.

8. **Minimum Testing Duration**: Analysis suggests 1000 hours is the practical minimum for reliable 25-year extrapolation when using multi-stress testing at 3+ conditions. Testing for 500 hours increases prediction uncertainty to ±40-50%, while 2000+ hours reduces it to ±15-20%. However, this assumes appropriate stress levels and proper statistical analysis.

9. **Integration with Hypothesis Testing**: For validating H1-H4, the accelerated testing framework must include: (a) Compositional series testing (varying Cs content 0-20% for H1, different SAM molecules for H2, various 2D/3D ratios for H3, different interlayer materials for H4); (b) Mechanistic probes during aging (impedance spectroscopy for ion migration, photoluminescence for phase segregation, XRD for phase stability); (c) Failure analysis at multiple degradation stages to identify dominant mechanisms; (d) Control experiments isolating individual stress factors.

10. **Commercial Viability Considerations**: While this research focuses on scientific validation, commercial implementation requires balancing testing rigor with cost and time constraints. Industry typically cannot wait 1000+ hours for product qualification. Developing rapid screening tests (100-200 hours) that correlate with longer-term performance is essential for commercialization, though these may have higher uncertainty (±30-40% for 25-year predictions).
